entry.title: A simple way to draw for Christmas Kindle
entry.summary: A christmas kindle way to draw with R or Python
entry.content:
A much simpler Christmas kindle draw by simple permutation (sample).

Idea : Keep it simple

R Code

Using R this gives the following

simple_secret_santa <-function(names){
   n = length(names)
   s <- sample(names, n, replace = FALSE)
   final <- cbind(s,rep('give to',n),c(s[2:n],s[1]))
   final
}

It guarantees that nobody gives to himself, and it also prevent circular gifting - ie A give to B and B give to A (except if there is only 2 persons).

And we can use it simply like this:

names <- c('Robert','Anna','Louis','Joseph','Mary','Antoine','Alex')
simple_secret_santa(names=names)
Person 'give to' Person
'Robert' 'give to' 'Louis'
'Louis' 'give to' 'Joseph'
'Joseph' 'give to' 'Anna'
'Anna' 'give to' 'Antoine'
'Antoine' 'give to' 'Mary'
'Mary' 'give to' 'Robert'

Python code

The same code in python gives

import random

def simple_secret_santa(names):
  n = len(names)
  s = random.sample(names,k=n)
  for i,name in enumerate(s):
    if i == len(s)-1:
      to = s[0]
    else:
      to = s[i+1]
    print str(i+1) + "   "+name + ' gives to ' + to

names = ('Robert','Anna','Louis','Joseph','Mary','Antoine','Alex')
simple_secret_santa(names)

Which gives us:

|1|Alex|gives to|Anna| |2|Anna|gives to|Mary| |3|Mary|gives to|Robert| |4|Robert|gives to|Antoine| |5|Antoine|gives to|Louis| |6|Louis|gives to|Joseph| |7|Joseph|gives to|Alex|

References

  • SECRET SANTA PICKER USING R

  • SECRET SANTA PICKER USING R 2

entry.title: Reboot
entry.content:
Time to reboot this blog.... After 2 years without new posts, time to dig myself again in data analysis.

I have also decided to widen the range of topics, so this blog will now explore various projects and ideas. It will cover my interests: - statistics and probability - data analytics and Machine Learning - Integrated circuit design and physical implementation - programming, algorithms and python - economics - data visualisation - and more as I will be guided by my inspiration.

entry.title: Hacking my way into Data science .... or at least trying
entry.content:
So I have this silly idea, to change career and move into Data Science, yes that very hyped field at this moment, hyped by the success of Amazon, Google, the writings of Nate Silver, books like "Moneyball", the falling costs of data accumulation.

In my defense I had that idea for good few years. When I was a kid, I tinkered with the data of games I played on my computer; like plotting dreadful pie chart representing my type of plane usage in a WWII combat flight simulator video game. Later I have also tried to put more data driven decision in my own engineering career. You would imagine that being an engineer, that most of my work would be data driven, but actually half of my career was more driven by aesthetics and some weird perception of artistry (you can read about the art of layout and my job there ).

Data Science - I am not a big fan of that name, but until I find a better one, I'll stick to that -  has gained loads of attraction, so much hyped that recently some have announced that the bubble was bursting: "The bubble is bursting because what I am seeing is more and more tools coming to market (soon) that will drive data science into the day-to-day job of all business people."

As a consequence more and more people are trying to get into this field (not necessarily a good thing for me, since that mean more competition),  but also more demands as more and more companies realize that they'd like to use the potential of data analytics, data driven decision making and predictive analytics.

I am quite fond of the following definition for data scientist: "A data scientist is someone who is better at statistics than any software engineer and better at software engineering than any statistician." And fancy myself fitting into that venn diagram.
Finding a place to fit in ?

Somehow I can visualize myself right at the center of this diagram.

So how do you get into the field when you have no credentials, no experience ....

My initial plan was:

1. Get some credentials, by going back to college (Msc). In particular reinforce my statistical knowledge.
2. Find a basic entry position, to gain experience and work from there.

The plan was quite simplistic and overly optimistic.

I don't think I got it too much wrong, but I underestimated the amount of learning, training and more especially practice I would have to go through.

I have know recognize this error and I am working towards fixing this. I also been comforted in my views, by a lightning talk by @saoili in Pycon Dublin on how to bootstrap a programming career.

So few lessons:

Number 1:
Practice is key ! Whatever you learn, practice it, over and over.
Somehow I knew that, because when I started my engineering career, that is exactly what I have done, but it seems I forgot that over the years.

Number 2:
Put all you learn into practice, ask questions to yourself, to others, fail, and learn from your mistakes and failures, then practice again. Try new things, experiment. Accept that failure is part of the process. I am more and more convinced that if I do not fail at one stage ( or multiple ), I have learned nothing new, or I haven't tried hard enough. Ask for help, if you are stuck.

Number 3:
Share your knowledge. Whatever the small amount you managed to master or understand, go and try to explain it to someone else, teach others, help them to discover how to do this.

I did go back to college, to pursue a Msc in Statistics in UCD. The program and experience were great, but I struggle. Weirdly I struggled on the most basic concept of statistics, which I had forgotten since I was last in college or never assimilated. In the end, I used online resources to help my comprehension, I probably could have done this before starting college, which would have got me better results.

Online learning resources ( starting from all levels) for statistics:

  • Khan Academy Probability and statistics track:
    https://www.khanacademy.org/math/probability 

  • Harvard Stat 110: Probability (available freely on Itunes)

  • Coursera in particular Johns Hopkins University Data Science.

I also realized that my programming skills were stucked into scripting mode (perl, tcl, any unix bash shell). So I went onto upgrading myself, initially using R, but more and more with Python.

Online learning resources for programming - focusing on Python:

  • CodeAcademy ( http://www.codecademy.com/en/tracks/python )

  • Learn Python the hard way ( it will encourage you to practice over and over ).
    http://learnpythonthehardway.org/book/

  • MIT online free course see itunes check: http://ocw.mit.edu
    In particular the intro to Computer Science.
-----

Practice

Off course, as previously stated, practice is key, and there some handful website to practice your programming (python skills):

Practicing python programming:
  • Project Euler, mathematics problem to be solved with some programming.
    https://projecteuler.net/

  • Checkio.org, a set of challenge in Python.
    http://www.checkio.org/

To practice data analytics and statistics: coursera and KHANACADEMY includes exercises and homework, but after that, you can compete in real problems:
  • Kaggle competition: https://www.kaggle.com/
    The site include tutorial on machine learning, decisions tree, I would recommend to go through (Titanic and Digits challenges)
How do you start practising ? find a problem to solve, an issue you are curious, and jump right in from there.

Sharing.
Also the following resources turned helpful to share your code, find solution when you are stuck, meet like minded people.
  • github ( https://github.com/ ) to show off your code, and browse the code of others.

  • Stack overflow ( https://stackoverflow.com/ ): brilliant resource for anything you may get stuck in. Also once you've become proficient, share and help others.

  • meetup ( http://www.meetup.com/ )  to find local people with similar interests.

  • python.ie, if you are in Dublin, IE, very active community.
After a couple of months here is my updated plan ( and more detailed):


  • Become (reasonably) proficient in :
    • Statistics, and statistical methods.
      • Possibly pass a professional examinations in statistics from the Royal Statistical Society
    • programing / computer stuff.
      • python and numpy, scipy, scikit.
      • R and package like ggplot2.
      • sql, hadoop, mapreduce database management.
  • Share knowledge, meet other data scientist, pythonista..
    • Contribute to Stackoverflow.
    • Publish more of my projects on this blog.
    • Participate in data analytics, use Kaggle, DataKind....
  • Apply for jobs in the desired area. (many many many times.... )

    I still like to get better credentials - I do have now a Higher Diploma in Statistics from UCD not the initial desired Msc  - , to help build my resume, but that is no longer a priority. I know and realize that I have much more to learn.

    Will I succeed in hacking my way there ?

    I don't know, but I will try.

entry.title: Random thoughts from Pycon Dublin
entry.content:
Over the weekend I attended my first Pycon in Dublin, Ireland. It is organised by the wonderful crowd of Python Ireland, I would actually recommend that you go to one of their monthly meetups if you have any interest in the Python language. !day 2 Main stage

I was not sure what to expect, but the experience turned out to be truly enjoyable, and I finished up the weekend, my head full of ideas to investigate with python.

Here's my favourite highlights of the weekend, in no particular order.

  • Ian Ozsvald @ianozsvald The Real Unsolved Problems in Data Science You can read it there:http://ianozsvald.com/2014/10/11/my-keynote-at-pyconireland-2014-the-real-unsolved-problems-in-data-science/

  • A lightning talk by @saoili about getting into python jobs, which comfort me in my current chosen path.

See her lightning talk slides. - On the same lightning talk show, a very entertaining demonstration of failing at data science (Homeless cloud by an engineer from rehabstudios, I forgot the name), but also a silent presentation by @dontusethiscode

  • Rachel Willmer @rwillmer in her keynote: A Tech Person's Adventures in Startup, gave me some inspiration and food for thoughts on creating your own company.

  • I realize that Python was widely used in the financial industry (something I did not know before ) thanks to Dr. Yves J. Hilpisch @dyjh keynote : Python and the Financial Industry.

  • Finally a very cool demonstration, inside iPython notebook on how to build an earth centered universe by Brandon Rhodes @brandon_rhodes.

Overall fun, exciting and energizing conference, I will probably be back next year, more engaged.

entry.title: Reading list
entry.summary:
The number of Books on data science and visualisation have bloomed in recent years, see below a list of my recent favourites

Mathematics history:

  • Theory That Would Not Die: How Bayes' Rule Cracked the Enigma Code, Hunted Down Russian Submarines, and Emerged Triumphant from Two Centuries of Controversy by Sharon …
entry.content:
The number of Books on data science and visualisation have bloomed in recent years, see below a list of my recent favourites

Mathematics history:

  • Theory That Would Not Die: How Bayes' Rule Cracked the Enigma Code, Hunted Down Russian Submarines, and Emerged Triumphant from Two Centuries of Controversy by Sharon Bertsch McGrayne Fascinating stories about the often forgotten and yet always resuscitated Bayes theorem, and quite insightful in how mathematics and science can also be a fierce battle between people holding different views.
  • Théorème vivant by Cédric Villani This book confirmed to me, I would never have the knack to become an academic.
  • Naked Statistics: Stripping the Dread from the Data by Charles Wheelan. Simple and entertaining introduction to statistical concept, I should have read that long ago, before going back to university.
  • Code: The Hidden Language of Computer Hardware and Software by Charles Petzold I found this book very accessible, and I like the way it started from the very basic without using electronic to go on to explain how our computer ( dominating our world ) works. The last chapters were a bit disappointing I have to say, probably a bit outdated, but I would recommend it to anybody who actually want to understand electronic hardware.
  • Information is Beautiful by David McCandless

Economics:

  • Freakonomics: A Rogue Economist Explores the Hidden Side of Everything by Steven D. Levitt, Stephen J. Dubner.
  • SuperFreakonomics: Global Cooling, Patriotic Prostitutes And Why Suicide Bombers Should Buy Life Insurance by Steven D. Levitt, Stephen J. Dubner. I simply love anything those guys do, ,either in podcast format or in book.
  • The Undercover Economist by Tim Harford. In the same vain, quite good at explaining basic economics concept and how they can apply to everybody daily life.

Data Science:

  • The Signal and the Noise: The Art and Science of Prediction by Nate Silver. Another bayesian book, you probably heard of Nate Silver, the book is not without default, but yet still a must read.
  • Untangling the Web: What the internet is doing to you by Aleks Krotoski. To understand how the web is changing our life, magnifying our humans traits.

Reference books:

I probably use those two books every other day to get examples of graphs, or ideas of coding.

  • Visualize This by Nathan Yau.

  • The Art of R Programming: A Tour of Statistical Software by Norman Matloff.

entry.title: Using Google Trends
entry.summary: Basic data exploration with Google trends.
entry.content:
Every time a story broke in the Irish newspaper, you can read "The eyes of the world are upon us", especially if the the story reflects badly on the Irish nation. I often think that Irish have an over-inflated impression of how other countries look at us, and the reality is that actually people in other countries have others stories ( local or nor ) to worry instead of caring about the Emerald Island.

So I had a look at Google Trends, relative to the latest "big" story, aka the cancellation of Garth Brooks concert in Dublin.

The site allow you to see what words are looked for in the google search engine, and display how many time specific words were used. The trends were used famously for the google flu detection. You can specify a time range, but also specific countries ( or cities ) , and compare different words.

So here we go. I used three words: Garth Brooks, Croke Park and Guinness. The last word is a sort of control, to gauge Irish interest across the world. Of course the choice of words can be improved, but i wanted a first initial taste.

So here the results for the last 30 days from Ireland:

Google Trends Ireland 30 days, Garth Brooks, Croke Park, Guinnes.




As the news broke, you can see the spikes in search terms, especially relatively to the control word.

But what about the rest of the world, certainly the USA must be watching this story:



Google Trends from USA



Well not really, there is a small bump, but not that high...

Looking at other countries,  France, Germany...  it seems outside Ireland people are quite indifferent about that story....



Google Trends from Germany 30 days


"{{ site.url }}/assets/screenshot.jpg)
x

A couple of comments on the graphs generated by Google Trends, there is no y-axis label.
Numbers represent search interest relative to the highest point on the chart. 
This doesn't convey absolute search volume.

From Google help:
"The numbers on the graph reflect how many searches have been done for a particular term, relative to the total number of searches done on Google over time. They don't represent absolute search volume numbers, because the data is normalized and presented on a scale from 0-100. Each point on the graph is divided by the highest point, or 100. When we don't have enough data, 0 is shown."
